data: Adversaries utilize invites to gain access to data
Adversaries use account recovery flows to gain additional information such as contact points or usernames.
Authentication tokens can contain excessive privileges. By checking the token's permissions, adversaries utilize the token for unintended access to additional (or deprecated) functionality.
Adversaries access data that is cached. Adversaries may choose this method to avoid directly querying the platform.
Adversaries access data directly from Content Delivery Network links. Adversaries may utilize this technique to evade logging and expected privacy controls.
Adversaries leverage information or behavior disclosed by error handling messages to learn secret information
Adversaries manipulate machine learning models such as recommendation systems to return information from the platform.
Adversaries take advantage of misconfigured privacy policies offered by the platform. For example, a user might set their birthday to be public when they mean for the setting to be private.
Adversaries abuse real-time communications to obtain data about others. For example, when communicating with others using peer-to-peer protocols such as WebRTC, IP addresses may be collected.
Adversaries utilize redirects to send traffic to their servers and steal personal data.
Adversaries leverage cached files on a server to access secret information.
Adversaries leverage typeahead suggestions to leak information.
Adversaries accept cryptocurrencies as a form of payment. Crytocurrencies may be used as a method of anonymization
Adversaries attempt to access personal or otherwise private data.
